rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Miller is a wonderful professor! She really cares about students and is very helpful if you go to her office hours.  She ends class early for homework questions and gives concise answers to questions. Tests are easy - definitely do the practice tests, and she allows a 1-page formula sheet. I definitely recommend her class.
Dr. Miller is an awesome prof!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Mitchell is a decent professor.  He just reads off the powerpoint slides (which he posts online) and doesn't add any more information.  Only tests on what he goes over in class, though the test was a lot harder than expected.  Decent for 201 though.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: A million details per lecture. One lecture is so dense with topics that it could honestly be an exam itself. Only 3 exams to make up your entire class grade.

Ignored peoples questions in class. Graded my test incorrectly and refused to correct it even after we looked over the key together during office hours. She'll expect you to explain concepts that she herself couldn't explain in class. Record the lectures and quote her on the tests because she'll take 5 out of 10 points off for missing one detail.

Comes across very scatterbrained and seems disinterested in engaging students who have questions following class. Test questions are broad, and not graded systematically (after checking the answer key, points were taken off for questions that were correct).

Terrible job of explaining anything. A couple questions each lecture were incompletely answered or left unanswered because she didn't know. Very disorganized in details of what we were covering at the time. Gets behind very quickly in lecture and test questions are too broad with specific unknown details expected.
This class was pretty hard, but it was also really interesting.  I think she did a good job of covering a lot of material and still getting into some of the controversies.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Bruno is awesome! Super chill guy, great professor, and his class isn't very hard. Do the basics and you'll be fine.
Loved him

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Easily the most boring class I have ever taken at this university. Could not pay attention in lectures, no matter how hard I tried, and the book and powerpoints are useless, making it impossible to study for the exams. Other stuff is easier, however, and I got a B while doing literally no work whatsoever.

Weakley is definitely knowledgeable and willing to help you out if you are struggling, but don't take this class expecting an easy A. There is a lot of memorization involved. If you put in the time though, you should get a good grade!

Very memorization heavy class. People tend to really like Weakley or really dislike. I liked him! He's a cool guy and lectures are pretty interesting. Not too much problem solving in a class like Local Flora, but tons of flashcards.

I LOVED this class, by far my favorite biology professor at UNC. He is so nice and really wants to get to know his students. He's also always willing to help. It's a lot of memorizing sometimes, but his tests aren't like those other bio classes that applies confusing concepts to some really hard problem. A class worth taking!

Best professor I have had at UNC. Extremely helpful, friendly, and intelligent man. Dr. Weakley is an amazing professor and his class is so much fun. He realizes that students don't care about their classes, so the class is entirely structured around how much each student puts into it. If you don't study, you won't do well, simple as that.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Slep was fairly decent. He's pretty monotonous and there is very little class engagement which makes it really hard to pay attention. If you study the power points though, the tests really aren't that difficult. As far as science professors go he was pretty good just not that interesting.

I enjoyed Professor Slep's lectures, but it's definitely not for everyone. He can be kind of monotone and not very exciting, but he covers the material well and will help if it is needed. His awkward jokes make the class more enjoyable, but his tests are very difficult, but they are doable if you thoroughly know the material. You WILL have to work.

His smoother than glass lectures make his co-instructors sound like bumbling fools. Tests will be hard for most, balance between understanding fundamentals and paying attention to lecture specifics. Hence, attendance is rewarded.
Test are long and too difficult compared to lectures and hw.

My fellow students, avoid Dr. Slep.  He gives tests that are nearly impossible to finish.  What's more, he told us before he even started teaching his section of the course that he didn't like the subject matter.  I'm a successful biology major right now, but this guy (first bio class I took at UNC) almost scared me away from the major entirely.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Amazing professor. Truly cares about his students. If you do the work and don't get behind on the readings, it's easy to do well. Also, his lectures are hilariousssss! and when I came a few minutes late to an exam one day and there were no more seats, he let me sit in the front so I'll have a desk. You can tell he truly cares about his students.

Fantastic lecturer. Anatomy is a lot of dense material but he explains it clearly. Also, Johnson records his lectures which is clutch af when studying. Be sure to get the poll everywhere question right! Correct answers give an extra bonus point. The tests are tough but they are completely fair and straight forward. TAKE HIM

Challenging class.  Soooooo much material, but you'll thank him later. Really great lectures.  There's some of the talk-to-your-neighbor BS like other bio classes but not too much.  This course helped me learn to READ, and I'm thankful for it.
Good lecturer

I would recommend him to anyone who is taking Anatomy and Physiology. It is definitely not a class you can easily pass by studying the day before. His exams are difficult but fair. Most of the exam questions are straight forward and some are tricky. Lab is a hard, so be careful and study a lot. He's such a cute and nice person.

Great lecturer.  The bio dept. needs more like him.  Tests were tricky, but very fair.  Purchase the bigger textbook.  The condensed one does not cover some of his lecture material.  That way, if you miss something from lecture, you can get it from the book.  Super approachable and caring; never felt rushed out the door in office hours.

Class uses both textbook and his lectures. There is a ton of information to learn but he does his best to make it fair albeit difficult. The first test was the easiest so don't slack especially on tests 2 and 3. He is engaging and committed to the class.

A pretty clear lecturer but boring. He's monotone and will throw around some jokes, but I honestly couldn't pay attention in class. Watch out cause his tests are tricky. Sometimes he takes more questions from the book info and sometimes more from his lectures/ppts. Nice guy and if you argue back for test points, he'll most likely give you one.

Awesome professor. As he says "Just know everything and you will be fine". Biol 252 is a had class, but if I would have to take it all over again, I would take it with him. I would take any possible class with him, loved him. He is a great teacher!

Professor Johnson is the best professor I have ever had. Take any and all courses you can with him. Heck, if he was teaching Intro to Women's Studies or History of Medieval Europe I would take that class. The subject matter is difficult for A&P, but he makes it interesting. The assignments are easy. The multiple-choice exams are not. Study a lot.

ONE OF MY FAVORITE PROFESSORS! Anatomy and Physiology is a lot of work! but his powerpoints are great! He always seems to cover everything you need to know without rushing. you have to do your part (study his ppts), but you can't claim your failure on him.

Love Dr. Johnson (so cute), but this class is hard. My advice - write down every single thing he says in class and study like crazy. Tests are fair but hard. He is great with email so def email him with questions (I did all the time). Lab is a pain b/c he writes the exams now, not the TAs, so lab is not as easy. Book is not really needed.
GREAT TEACHER!  Take him for A&P if you have the opportunity!!
I love Dr. Johnson! Probably the best professor I had at UNC.

By far the best professor I've had. Tells you exactly what will be on the exam (what's on the outlines). The book he chose is very good. Only tests you on material you go over in class although you need to know more details on those topics. Also very nice person who will be glad to help you with any problems.

Dr. Johnson is a sweet man & a good professor. He e-mails back very fast & is willing to meet with you/hold exam study sessions. BIOL in general is hard but straightforward so if you don't do well it's not his fault. His tests are completely reasonable & he makes little jokes in class. He also sometimes mentions his new daughter which is adorable.

Dr. Johnson is the best! He is readily available for office hours and his lecture notes are clear and concise. While I recommend that you read the textbook (it's helpful), you don't have to, since he only tests things that he covered in class. Plus, he is incredibly cute and fun to listen to!

I love Dr. Johnson!! :) Amazing professor. The class was at 8am but definitely worth coming to. Exams weren't too bad pretty straight forward but theres a ****ton of material, but thats for any class. Would definitely take him again for other bio classes.

Very nice guy. Extremely helpful and cares a lot about his student. Not an easy class...lots of memorizations but you bust you butt and you'll do well ;) Plus he gives you a chance to make up for you lowest grade if you improve well enough.

Great Professor. Unlike most bio profs he cares about his students. Funny, helpful, and makes class enjoyable. Outline notes are posted before lecture, which helps when the lecture material gets dull. Tests are fill in the blank & T/F, but he makes it clear what will and will not be on the test.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Hogan is a good teacher, but her tests are pretty challenging, even if you study thoroughly and feel prepared in regards to the material. Lots of application questions and the homework/GRQ (guided reading questions) and notes are pretty time consuming. You will learn a lot, but theres a good amount of work.

Dr. Hogan was an excellent teacher. I loved her as a person and how she was able to keep Biology exciting and fun. She made the class of over 400 people seem so much smaller by her teaching style. I didn't do very well in her class, unfortunately, because the exams are quite difficult. I would highly recommend this professor though!

Dr. Hogan was one of my favorite professors. She is a great teacher,  and although her tests are difficult, if you study hard you can do well. One thing I loved is that she often reminded us that grades don't define us and that there's more to life that school.
Awesome professor, but a challenging class nonetheless. Expect a lot of questions that require you to think abstractly and demonstrate mastery.

Dr. Hogan is a great lecturer and really cares to help her students.  Some exams may be tough, and online homework was annoying sometimes, but not too difficult and does help to understand the material.  Just attend class and you will do fine.

Dr. Hogan is super sweet and gives you all the resources she can to help you succeed. Lectures are interesting and she dumbs down the material in class to make sure everyone understands it. However, her tests are much much much more difficult than lectures make you think they will be. Overall, it was a good experience and I learned a lot.

TAKE HOGAN! Lectures are engaging. She's lowkey funny and super chill. Keep up with the readings, its a decent amount, but nothing crazy. There are learning catalytics questions daily for a participation grade. The class moves at a good pace. Tests aren't "easy", but if you do the work, you'll be fine. 10/10 would recommend!
Her format for teaching is incredible, and she really gives you all the tools you need to do well. Be prepared to do a lot on your own time, but a great class and professor.

Hogan is an amazing teacher. She is so passionate about science which makes a difficult subject enjoyable. Her lectures are very interesting and engaging. Her tests are very tough, but if you can devote a couple days to studying and keep up with notes and actually read the text you'll do fine. This class really taught me how to study the right way.

Kelly Hogan is outstanding! Her lectures are goal-oriented and in-depth. She deeply cares about her students and the material, listening to feedback and thoroughly reviewing confusing material. Her first two tests were okay, but the third one was difficult for the whole class. The final is rewarding if you keep up with the class.

Hogan is a phenomenal professor. I walked into this class extremely intimated and rightfully so. Hogan will help you no matter what - she is sweet and considerate and so passionate about biology. She really makes you work for your grade, but her class teaches you how to learn and how to study. I would definitely take her again. She's an inspiration

Dr. Hogan makes topics very interesting, she takes times with difficult subjects, she addresses concerns in class, and is very clear. Her tests are VERY hard but you actually learn instead of memorize it, a lot of work is required for this course but i would highly recommend her. She cares about you learning the material.

Dr. Hogan was an amazing professor for Biol 101. She gives adequate time on difficult biology matters and makes sure that she gets through everything she had planned on in the lecture. You have online mastering due twice a week, which some can take 30 minutes, others can take 2 hours. Over all, do the mastering and pay attention and come to class!
Honestly this class was hard if you never took AP Bio. This is where you learn if you were meant to be in the science field or not. She's a great person though! Definitely cares about her students.
As long as you go to class everyday, do all of your online assignments, and go to SI at least once a week you'll definitely get at least a C easily. B if you read your textbook.

Hogan is awesome! She's really nice and is a good resource not only for the biology department but for helping first-years get acquainted to UNC in general. The tests are SUPER hard and cover a lot of material. Make sure you stay on top of all the GRQs and homework so you can do well on the exams. There's 4 exams and she drops the lowest grade.

Hogan assigns a lot of work, but it pays off. It's a little annoying to have to participate so much in a big lecture class where you might rather just sit back and listen, but all of the things she makes you do for participation grade end up really helping you learn. She thinks a lot about how her students will learn best.

Hogan is a great professor assuming your comfortable doing the majority of work outside of class. Lectures are very helpful and extremely engaging. Hogan does her best in making herself available to such a large class.
She's really nice and funny. The lectures are pretty fun. You use your laptop to answer questions during class.

By far my favorite professor at UNC so far.  I was interested in biology already, but she made it very fun, interactive and I actually wanted to do the homework.  She truly cares about her students; when I got an A on a test, she personally emailed me to congratulate and keep up the good work. Her passion and excitement for learning was contagious.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I loved Dr. Corbin's class. He is a great teacher, and he is interesting and funny. There was no textbook, just papers posted on blackboard. The class was challenging, but not too hard. Attendance was not mandatory, but participation was a part of the grade.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Hurlbert is one of the worse professors I've had. The textbook is online and a complete waste of money. When you do the reading quizzes there is no way to check your answers until he posts them (which is not until the test comes around). He also refuses to let you make up an exam, even when you are excused for university functions. DO NOT take him.

He teaches out of this horrendous online textbook. His tests are out to trick you. In office hours, he is not particularly helpful to students. Lectures are pointless and he is not very good at explaining things

I was not looking forward to taking this class because I am not really interested in ecology or evolution, but Dr. Hurlbert is a great professor and is very good at keeping students engaged and makes sure we understand the material. Very helpful in lectures and in office hours. Tests are hard: aren't very many questions but are straight-forward.

Hurlbert is possibly the worst professor I have ever had.  He comes across as very patronizing, and his test questions have multiple correct answers, but its whichever one he feels is right. He tests out of the book on things not from lecture, which is ridiculous since there is so much reading.

This professor is the most boring professor you will ever have, especially if you are not interested in the material. He does not use the textbook at all so you have to go to every class and take extensive notes to get a good grade on his section of the exams. This class is on a curve so the exams are way harder than they need be so the curve is up

The professor should be nicer in office hours, however there is not a correlation between what he teaches in class which he teaches in class which superb; however,if you approach up to him for a question he answers your question with a question and tells you that you should know not only the material discussed in class but also in the textbook.

The professor is great in class lectures but is not very friendly in office hours when you ask questions pertaining to what you should focus. Today I went to his office and he treated me like I should not be in his course. It was just a bad experience and would warn people on the types of questions you ask. This was not a great experience.
Probably one of the most approachable professors at Carolina.  Definitely a very smart guy, although sometimes what he says might go over your head a little bit, but he is very nice and helpful.

Professor Hurlbert is AMAZING!  He is the best Bio Professor I have had at UNC!  He was on Franklin Street jumping Fires after we won during the Final Four.  He is really an amazing lecturer.  He is so interesting.  His test wasn't bad.  The average was higher than the first part of the course.  I cannot say enough how amazing he is!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: This guy copyrights all his lectures and will not hesitate to delete google docs. Your grade depends on 3 tests (including the final) so be sure to pay attention during class because he will talk on and on about this subject. He can be funny sometimes, never answers your emails, and does a weird calculation to your grade towards the end

Dr. Sockman is a great lecturer. He's very clear and funny about the topics. However, his slides are all pictures and attendance- while its not taken- is necessary to do well in the class. His class has no grades other than three tests- which may sound daunting but if you go to class everyday and take detailed notes it should be fine.

Professor Sockman single-handedly turn Biol 474 into my favorite class of my entire college career. He discusses a broad range of topics all applicable to almost every bio major class. Stress free class because he breaks everything down and can actually lecture. Definitely stick out the beginning, because he gradually becomes hilarious.

At first, Sockman was kind of intimidating and seemed difficult, but as the class went on he opened up a little and he is rather comical.  There are five tests (all multiple choice) and they are pretty difficult and require a great deal of studying to prepare for them, but there is a good curve at the end of the semester.

Class was not as interesting as I had hoped. Sockman is very friendly and open to questions during class and office hours. Multiple choice tests and final, one test is dropped. But material is detailed and tedious. Much is straight memorization of evolutionary changes but not the purpose behind them

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Servedio definitely knows what she is talking about. I'm not sure if it is her or the nature of the course, but it was very hard.  The average on our final was a 56. She was a decent lecturer, though sometimes didn't answer questions very well. The first test was very fair and kind of easy, but the final was killer.
She's very disorganized with the lectures and the exams are unpredictable and hard.

Dr. Servedio is a very nice lady who really knows her stuff, but she can't make a test to save her life.  And in a class that is all tests, this sucks.  I read the book, went to every lecture, and studied hours for the tests, and still made a C with the curve.  I asked her how to better study for my tests and she had NO IDEA!!

Servedio was great for 201H. She was incredibly passionate and helpful about the material although the class was far too much work for no extra credit hours. She was slightly unorganized for lectures but she was relatively clear, fair,and tried to make class interesting. Beware of the final; it was much harder than expected given the easy midterms.

Good professor who is very approachable and legitimately interested in the material.  Anyone who says "material on tests is not in lectures" is dead wrong.  I got 100's on her tests and never cracked the book.  Go to class and LISTEN to what she's saying, take responsibility for the material, and you'll do well and learn a lot about evolution.
She makes the material much harder than it actually is. She doesn't do a good job explaining and often rush things in lectures. Basically you need to study on your own...

the course itself is not that hard, but her lectures are worthless. she posts just limited numbers of plain photos as her lecture, and just barely touches the material that is needed to know. she said not to buy the book, but you defenatly need the book, b/c you won't get anything from lecture. ask TAs or help.

She is a great person.  I really like her!  She thinks like I do which was useful for me on her test.  She really just wants you to think about the stuff more so than "memorizing stuff you will forget."  This was the one bio class i dreaded taking, but I actually LOVE it!  Her tests are somewhat tricky, but not impossible.  It is a bio class.
I thought the class was interesting and I didn't have too hard a time with it.  If you like evolutionary theory and/or math you'll like it, otherwise I'd imagine its pretty painful

Lectured through powerpoints which only gave limited information. Her tests required much more than mere memorization and application. Anyone without a sufficient background in Evolution  should run from her!!!

Terrible professor. The material, which should be really easy, was not taught well at all...she told us not to buy the book, but then her tests were nearly impossible. If you want to get a good grade I suggest you go against her advice and buy the book and teach yourself.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Before I decided to take his class, I remember visiting this site. I remember many people saying that this was the professor that they had ever had, and now, I think the same thing. However, don't underestimate the work load. Anatomy in general is tough, but you are still expected to know just as much as any other course.

Great lecturer, who knows his stuff. If you're fascinated by the human body, this class will give you the satisfaction of deeply exploring its marvels. I must say that since 92% of your overall grade is test average, the pressure to perform is always there... which amounts to many hours of studying notes and textbook material.
Dr. Shemer is a genius and makes class really interesting. The tests are fair for what is covered in lecture, but sometimes the multiple choice is tricky

Great teacher! Shemer is very knowledgeable about biology and answers any questions you have really well or to the best of his ability. He assigns just the few pages of reading that you need and goes over topics in detail during class so everything that will be on the test will be explained in person. Take lots of notes during lecture.

Dr. Shemer is the best professor I've encountered in the biology department. His lectures are clear and well organized, he's interactive with the class, and takes questions often and seems to really care if we understand the material.  He gives a lot of practice for the tests and his review sessions are super helpful.

Shemer is one of the most intelligent lecturers I have ever had. He makes attending lecture interesting and worth my while. There is a TON of material, but that is with the nature of the class. He also only has two exams, and then the final, so there is more pressure on those two classes. You really cannot find a better professor for the material.

The class is hard, but very fair. Shemer is a great teacher and gives lots of resources for extra help. If you study the material along the way and don't wait until the weekend before the test, you'll be fine. Lab is worth a big part of your grade, so study hard for that too and you'll be fine

Great professor. Very funny, loves what he teaches, crystal clear. His exams are not bad, makes you think and apply your knowledge, if you study his notes and understand the material well, you'll be fine
Passionate, interesting, knowledgeable, and humorous.  His exam are fair but challenging.  I highly recommend him for A&P.
He is fabulous. hard and expects a lot from his students but truly one of the best at UNC. He is a must!

Shemer is passionate about what he teaches and truly tries to integrate the entire class in his lectures. But his tests are very unfair. I studied for weeks before and still did badly on them. He even said in class "I know that some of you are studying a lot and still doing bad. Don't be discouraged." Great, but my Gpa is messed up bc of this! :/

He is very funny and a nice guy! His lectures are interesting, but his tests are the hardest tests I have ever taken. I would put in over 20 hours studying and just do decent on the test. Also you HAVE to go to class. He tests you on stuff that he just says in class and is not in the book or on powerpoints.

Very difficult class, especially for someone who is not interested in science. However, I absolutely loved this class. I enjoyed going every day. His tests are very hard, but he's also clear on what to expect. Study hard and often, and enjoy his funny lectures!

Anatomy with Shemer was one of my favorite classes at UNC. It was entertaining, interesting, & funny & he was always available in office hours. Exams were challenging but it was clear what to expect; they were multiple choice, t/f, & fill-in-the-blank, requiring higher-level thinking. He scheduled exams so they wouldn?t conflict with lab exams.
An all around good fellow. He has high expectations not for the purpose of maintaining a curve, but because he is genuinely concerned if you do well.

He is INCREDIBLE!  He is so interested in the subject matter and he brings a lot of energy to the class, so lectures are a lot of fun.  He talks quickly, so I would recommend a recorder.  He also offers extra credit for a few people if they want to write a song about anatomy and perform it!  He is always willing to give additional explanations.

Prof. Shemer is one of the best professors I've ever had.  Although the course isn't easy due to the breath of material covered, Shemer is very clear in explaining what you need to know.  He's entertaining, keeps the class engaged and his powerpoints are very helpful.  Definitely recommend this class! (but must you must study regularly to do well).

This class is pretty hard but he is definitely a great teacher. He really cares that you learn the material. Just make sure you the information like the back of your hand. Would definitely suggest this class.

Awesome teacher! Difficult material, but what else would you expect with the human body. His speech is hard to understand at times but he does all he can to help you out. Overall this was one of my favorite classes at UNC.
Loved him!  No curve though.  Class is really fun, and he's hilarious.  Make sure you go to class and read.  This was my favorite class at Chapel Hill.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: This class was insanely hard, most of us did it for the EE credit. The exams quizzes were brutal and they would take off points for the most nit-picky reasons. Lectures were long-winded and she often left out details. If you aren't interested in plant fossils or have no previous knowledge about plants, do not take this class.
studied more for each exam and steadily got worse grades :( she crams as much time as much material in as she possibly can-lab last day of class, project due last week. lab is very easy though

really sweet person & a terrific teacher. she is really enthusiastic about plants, especially fossils. you will have to learn a good bit of information but her tests are very reasonable. labs can be kinda boring but they're important for quizzes & tests. if she shows you a fossil, REMEMBER IT b/c it will show up again on a test or quiz.

Great teacher!! She is sooo nice & very clear. Take notes during lecture, read the book before the exam, check with her in office hours for any "holes" in your notes, go to lab...get an A/B..you choose! She apparently loves what she is teaching. (By the way..I HATED the idea of taking this course and I normally do horrible in bio courses!)

Great teacher!! She is sooo nice & very clear. Take notes during lecture, read the book before the exam, check with her in office hours for any "holes" in your notes, go to lab...get an A/B..you choose! She apparently loves what she is teaching. (By the way..I HATED the idea of taking this course and I normally do horrible in bio courses!)

Dr. Gensel is robably the best professor I've had. her lectures are crystal clear, and the labs are easy and help give tangible examples of what is taught in class. Sheoffers lots of field trips and tons of time outside of class to help you if you're struggling. Her tests are reasonably difficult, but you're in the bio department; get used to it.

Wow, what a great professor. She's always happy and extremely enthusiastic which makes learning fun. Labs are very laid-back and easy. Going to class is important but not required. Tests are tough but not impossible. Best bio prof I've had yet.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: She Lacks of knowledge, specially in advance material.  Also, she is never wrong, so do not contradict her.  Not the best choice to learn.

One of the best professors I've ever had!! Her class is tough but interesting and once you get to the upper level classes you'll be glad you had her. Plus she gives you a bunch of resources to do well as long as you put the work in on your end you'll do well. She's very kind and helpful in office hours too. Absolutely would recommend.

I think the problem is that Professor Steinwand doesn't understand how difficult her exams are. I would study so much, not even cramming, and still make right at or even below the average. It was very hard to understand what many of the questions were asking and not having practice tests didn't help either. Try to get someone else if possible.

I don't like the course style of our biology department actually, too much meaningless thing actually distract me from learning it. And the professor cannot measure the toughness of test at all, which sometimes become super easy and sometimes become super hard. And the knowledge point which we should study is like super vague.

Teaches at a very elementary level with simple examples and very surface level lectures and many complain that the tests are unfair because of their difficulty and length. However, I feel like you can get used to the style of questions. If you do the SI problems and go through the PPT examples, you'll be fine on the tests. Didn't learn much overall

I took this as a freshman and it was my first Bio class at UNC, do not make this your first bio class here! I did terrible on the 1st exam, mediocre on the 2nd, and phenomenal on the 3rd. The amount I studied for each exam didn't change and the class average didn't really change either; you just have to get used to her type of tests.

One of the worst teachers I have ever seen. Her way of grading tests and asking test questions is bad. In lecture, she will show you a "practice question" and you'll see something similar only to find out that there is some kind of trick involved. If something seems easy on an exam, you're doing it wrong. This may seem biased, but do not take her.

i'm sure she's a great person but she sucks so much as a professor. Her exams are unfair and she wastes class time going over trivial stuff then tests you on things you've never gone over. Tests are way too long for the allotted time and you spend half your time trying to understand what she is asking.

Great teacher, but DOESN'T WRITE FAIR EXAMS. The exams are designed to trick you instead of test your knowledge of the material, so it doesn't matter how much you study. Test questions are based off of things she very briefly mentions and not practice problems or what she spends the most time on.

Her GRQs and even exams are riddled with spelling mistakes. She projects the material in a very simple fashion and then expects you to integrate the knowledge into analytical questions on the exam. This would be fine, were it not for the confusing and ambiguous nature of the tests and their answers. I would recommend finding a different teacher.

If you like working in groups and discussions, you will love this class. If you like traditional lecturing classes, this professor might not be for you. Like everyone has said before me, her exams are tough but in my opinion reasonably fair.
In lecture it feels like all of the concepts are really easy and then she makes the tests far more challenging compared to the depth of lecture.

I loved Dr. Steinwand's class. You definitely have to do the reading ahead of time to know what's going on in class, but it's totally worth it. A large portion of the tests are experimental design, but it makes the tests better because you learn how to apply the concepts you're learning. And Dr. Steinwand is super clear and a great professor!!

Tests are so hard and not based off of what you cover in class or the reading. DO NOT TAKE HER. Her outlines seem helpful but she tries to claim a stern title as a newbie in the Bio department. She assigns grades based off of what type of student she thinks you are.

Dr. Steinwand is truly a genuine teacher. She works so hard to work with and help students. She's not an easy teacher by far - you have to be prepared to do work on your own. But she makes that clear and she supplements all that you learn on your own with important knowledge on applying what you learn. Overall an amazing mentor and professor!

205 is my second class with Dr. Steinwand and I had her for 202. She is nice, but she treats her classroom as an elementary style classroom.  Her lectures seem simple and watered down, but her concept of applying the material makes her tests difficult and ambiguous. Oh, and don't challenge her exam questions or she will bite your head off.

The flipped classroom can be a great thing. This professor does not do the flipped classroom well at all. The material is challenging enough without having to show up to class already having internalized it. EVERYTHING is a group activity. NOTHING is explained in lecture. A "70" is a "good average exam grade." Spare yourself.

Steinwand is awful. Her tests are extremely hard and are basically designed to trick you. She's very unhelpful in office hours and even less helpful in lecture. She rushes through material and often answers questions by saying "find it in your textbook."

Never had more mixed feelings about a teacher. A very forthcoming lady--she invited us over to her house for dinner and really seemed to enjoy getting to know our individual interests relevant to the course. However, her harsh grading will surprise you, and unless you study for the exams in a very "Steinwand-specific way" you will struggle.

She is so great to students. I consider her a mentor for life. So glad I took her class. I'm a transfer student and learned a lot about studying and how caring people at Carolina are through her. Organized. Gives a ton of resources. Hard but fair.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Bloom loves his subject and this comes across in the lectures.  He does tend to get on tangents but is overall a great professor.  I always enjoyed his lectures, although they do switch professors half way through the semester for this class which was kind of annoying.

VERY passionate about his subject, and he knows his stuff. I'm not going to lie, he does go on tangents and it's a little fuzzy until he gets to his main point. However, he's very knowledgeable and makes an 8 am genetics class worth it. He's bad about answering emails though... and his second exam was a lot tougher than the first. Very nice man!
Hard class. Make sure you get the assigned readings done and pay attention to details he not only makes his exams from lecture but a lot of it comes from the readings. Hard exams.

He was obviously very knowledgeable but not able to communicate ideas to the class.  He jumped from subject to subject during lecture so it was hard to follow and take notes.  His tests were hard, but if you paid attention in class, read the textbook, and reviewed masteringgenetics, they were fair.

He liked what he taught but was very disorganized. He's one of those professors that's definitely a great researcher, but NOT a good at teaching. He assumes that you know about a LOT of things beforehand. The exams were extremely ambiguous and hard, especially the 1st one. Also, he never showed up to class on the days we had exams. NEVER.

He is a nice guy and means well and is very passionate about what he teaches. That being said he is very tangential in his lectures and kind of disorganized, so it ends up being quite confusing. Exams are crazy hard, i know many classmates that thought they had a firm grasp on the material that ended up nearly failing the tests.

He introduces an idea, goes to something else, then comes back to finish his point; the end result is sometimes confusing. Not very personable and his test questions are left fielders (even for me and I had a solid A), be ready for curve balls! But, he knows his stuff big time. Minus a couple of nasty test questions, exams are actually very fair.

Dr. Bloom is disorganized, does not explain concepts well, bounces to another concept without thoroughly explaining the first one.  He writes confusing tests and does not clearly express how he would like the questions to be answered.  Biology is a culture and he doesn't do a very good job in helping students integrate into that culture. Avoid him!

Bloom is not a good teacher. He rambles, and refuses to use any kind of technology to teach except Lego blocks (yeah, you read correctly!) and an overhead projector--he seems quite proud of this, too. Tests are somewhat hard, especially the first one. Do yourself a favor and take the other section of this clas.

I enjoyed Dr. Bloom's lectures much better than Dr. Dangl's.  Bloom went slowly through the more complicated material, which was very helpful.  I wouldn't recommend taking this class because as a pair, Bloom and Dangl make this class very difficult to understand

I'm a double science major and Bloom's class was by far my easiest science class at UNC.  He teaches the complicated parts patiently and the practice tests he gives are very helpful.  Do the practice tests and go to review sessions and this class is no problem.
The material isn't easy, but he's very approchable for questions after class.
I did not think either Kerry Bloom or Jeff Dangl were effective teachers. This class contains difficult material and I would advise taking it with someone else.

Somewhat scatterbrained, but generally a good teacher. Stops frequently for questions and goes slowly through difficult material, very much unlike his colleague (and co-professor) Jeff Dangl. Average-difficulty or difficult tests. Likes what he does, so learning from him is a bit easier.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I took this class for Evans first semester of teaching. I was shocked by how difficult biology became, since I always made A's in every biology class I took in high school. Go to the lectures for online participation but don't expect to better understand material. She makes class content confusing and doesn't offer much help for students.

I like Dr. Evans but I hated having her in class. She treated us like we were children, and the videos we watched were not very helpful. My main problem with her was the fact that she was very rude during office hours. She made me feel like I was wasting her time by being there. Also she loves trick questions, so watch out.

Evans didn't her use her time wisely in class. She made the class watch videos that just made the content even more confusing. It is a very flipped classroom and tests are difficult, however... she lets you drop your lowest exam grade which is nice. If you want to do well in this class, you must work for it.
She can hold a laser pointer extremely steady, it's actually quite uncanny

Dr. Evans was not a very good lecturer, in fact she didn't really lecture at all. She asks you questions to discuss with your neighbor, but then she never tells you the correct answers to the questions. I found her annoying and not very helpful.
great professor but she makes you learn it through in class discussion and activities

I don't know what the other ratings on here are talking about because I loved Dr. Evans. As a junior I have taken a multitude of other biology classes and found Dr. Evans to be one of the most helpful & clear professors. With participation in lecture I needed minimal work outside the class to secure an A. LOVED her so ignore other posts & take her

This class is easy. If you know the basics of biology its pretty much an easy A. You don't need the test book at all or need to show up to class. I skipped class over ten times and still have an A in the course. The only difficult part is maybe the first section but as long as you show up to the SI session you will get all the material need.

All of her tests except for the first one are easy. At the end of the Semester I did not show up to class for over a month and still have a high A going into the final. Dr. Evans however is not a very good teacher, she is terrible at explaining things and spends all of her class time focusing on topics not relevant to the tests. Would not recommend
She doesn't teach. Be prepared to "turn to the person next to you to discuss" during the lecture. But good luck because they probably don't know what's going on either!

Hour&15 minute long lectures are usually based on "group" discussion of a worksheet of questions that could be answered individually in less than 15 minutes. Often gives incorrect information during class, asks test questions that are purposely misleading. Make sure you DO overthink test questions, the answer is often not what seems most logical.

I really enjoyed this class. The lectures are usually pretty fun even if you have to learn outside the class by doing the homework. The first unit is A LOT harder than the others, so don't be daunted. The first unit has a lot more homework and a harder test. After that, though, most of the class is very basic vocabulary and pretty logical.
Doesn't teach. There are times where she doesn't know what she's talking about and can't help solve problems because she can't do them herself.
Live by the text book and you still won't succeed. Ask her questions and she will just read off of her notes again.

Dr. Evans is not a good teacher. She spends too much time on irrelevant things during lecture when we could have gone over important material from the tests. She asks a lot of questions that no one knows the answer to. Tests are nothing like the material she goes over in class. Very difficult.

Dr. Evans is enthusiastic and caring, but I would HIGHLY recommend taking Hogan instead. Dr. Evans is still new to teaching, and it shows. There were questions on exams that had NO RIGHT ANSWER. The lectures are all about trying to learn from classmates who also don't know anything. If you can teach yourself and go to SI, you'll be alright though.
Go to office hours!
I basically used the textbook to teach myself, and lectures were nothing but working with the people around you and you never got the correct answers to questions. 12
Dr. Evans doesn't lecture. She wants you to work with the people around you to learn and doesn't always give the correct answers to her guided notes/outlines for the powerpoints.

Took this class as a prereq for pre-med, she's a really nice person and loved meeting her! It was her first year teaching and I studied a lot for this class so I did well, but I know that some people didn't really like her. If you take notes on your own and go to class you will be fine. Can be confusing at times. Textbook was my life.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Please I you love your life NEVER take this class

Bob Peet is super smart, knows his material, and lecutres old school.  Keep up, listen for intellectual humor, and work as hard as you ever thought you would.  If you want to know ecology or plants, take his class.  If you want an easy A, drop it.

DO NOT take this course. I had hoped to dig deeper into ecological issues, but all I have experienced is frustration and high expectations.  Peet's lectures are unorganized and do not convey information well. You would think after decades of teaching that he would be a proficient lecturer.  There are more things to life than your class, Bob!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: No. Never again. Just don't, take it online at any other school. Just not with her. She brings in grant money so somehow they give her access to students. But honestly she should not be within a 20 mile radius of a student. Thank you for singlehandedly ruining my love of microbiology, business it is..

Worst professor I have ever had at Carolina. Every day our lecture consisted of her making general statements that did not match up with the power points. Almost every test you take you will have to resubmit for a regrade because of how many mistakes that are made. I can say that this class has been more stress than it's worth and she needs to go.

go to class, write down everything she says, even if it doesn't sound important (because oftentimes it is). do the practice exams and study in a group. don't approach her outside of office hours without an appt. do all that and you will be fine.

Worst teacher I've ever had. She is condescending, extremely difficult to approach, and definitely not the easiest person to look at. The perpetual sneer on her face was a testament to how she didn't want you to succeed. Oh, the book was of no use either.

This class is a nightmare. Dr. M laughs at her own jokes, runs into her own desk so much, she bruises herself. The class is such a waste! All you do is memorize old test, if you actually read the material you are screwed!I would not recommmend it to my worst enemy!

Horrible teacher.  You will learn very little and be engaged even less.  All you do is memorize old tests because knowing the material from the book won't help you at all.  She even tells you that if you do the reading you will make a C- on her tests.  Condescending, pretentious and not at all helpful.  Read a book on your own.  You'd be better off

If you're a seasoned microbiologist,you'll do fine. ^.> Expects entirely too much on tests.Studying won't help much. Class was at 8,had to come in at 730 to be able to finish exams(90% of people were still there at 845). Grades harshly.Ran overtime often.Memorize old tests;if you want to learn, avoid. Gave us 2 min to do evaluations, of course.

Matthysee is a sweet woman, but the class is very hard, the tests are very hard (all tests are cumulative with difficult tricky questions), unlimited studying may not help you.  Hard to follow but if you need the class only she teaches it.
No Comments
Fairly difficult material.

A difficult professor to get ahold of outside of her office hours.  The difficulty of this class requires some office visits.  If your hours don't match hers, look for a tutor or another course.  She is the only professor that teaches this class.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Probably the best professor in the biology department and one of the best at UNC. Very helpful in class and office hours and just a really nice guy in general. Try to take his Biol 451 class if you can!
Amazing class! Professor Kier loves the material and makes it interesting with the use of demos and simple physics. You end up learning the theory and aren't just memorizing.

By far one of the best classes i've taken at unc. he was a great prof and very enthusiastic about the material,which was contagious. the material itself was really interesting. definately recommend this class!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Tests are very straightforward. She talks quietly and teaches using figures on a powerpoint. As long as you take notes during lecture and read, you should be fine. She gives you a lot of practice exams, and her tests are VERY similar to some of the questions she gives as practice. She teaches the molecular portion.

Dr. Searles is probably one of the better science professors I've had at UNC, especially when it comes to explaining concepts and being knowledgeable in her field, which is important when people are asking off-the-wall questions.  She was very approachable in office hours and I felt like she wanted me to succeed.  Tests were extremely fair!!!

Dr. Searles is great for the second half of 202. She's hard, but her tests are very fair and straight for lecture material. Definitely read and do recitationSI problems.  Very helpful in office hours.  Provides lots of practice exams for each test.

For molecular half of class. Her lectures can get a git boring at times and I have to wake up. If you pay attention she does lay out the material well and answers questions. Her tests are hard but fair and not tricky. Compared to other bio teachers her tests are a relief, but all short answerfill in. Recitation problems are important.
I had her for the Molecular half of 202 and it was TERRIBLE. Boring and unclear lectures and the test? Very hard. She seems like a nice person though

This was a challenging but very rewarding course.  We focused on learning to read scientific papers.  each week a few students presented but all had to participate.  Dr. Searles put in a lot of time making sure you were ready for your presentation and we learned a lot!
Terrible lecturer, but her tests are fair. Do all your recitation problems and make sure you understand them before exams.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Jones is very knowledgeable and eager about this course. It is nice to have a professor who truly knows so much on one topic. Record his lectures and read the book and you should be fine! Recitation is easy it is just 3-5 hw problems from the book per week... not bad at all! Take him for 205!

The class is awsome. Jones is terrific.  If you are not a serious student, then don't bother because you'll just complain like some of these other babies are doing who marked this class poor.If you are serious- this is a must-take class.
I have terrible memories of his class.

This professor is belittling and is not approachable for help or guidance. This professor is knowledgeable and his lectures are understandable. His tests are very tricky multiple choice. The tests do not represent the material covered in lectures. If you have an opportunity to take another professor, then do. He is not recommended.
The test were hard as****, and the recitations were not easy either
extremely excited about the course, is clear and fair. wants students to do well but the course is pretty difficult as a whole.
Terrible teacher, incredibly hard, good luck staying awake
very clear-  the course is a must for those interested in cells- he does a great job covering a lot about cells in just 7 weeks.exams are tough but he trys to be fair

He loves cell biology and he really seems like he wants us to understand how it is important in our lives. Very helpful and fair but firm with the class policy. The book material is important so don't blow it off. Forget about the recitations though. I didn't like cell biology before but am very interested now.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Peifer has a nice personality and seems to know what he is talking about but can be rather condescending. He obviously does not want to teach and makes it clear to you just how little he enjoys is as compared to his research. His tests are a little difficult and the material is awful, lots of random specific details that don't relate to anything.
He taught the developmental section of the class.  He's very condescending and just a jerk in general.  Wish I had taken the other section of BIOL 205 that he didn't teach.  Try to avoid him

Best teacher I've had from the biology department.  He's a bit quirky, like he wears funny hats to class a lot and actually brought in a live chicken one day, but that's what makes him so fun.  His tests are thorough, but fair, and he explains things well.  He's also really helpful outside of class.
No Comments
Very good about explaining things thourougly, but he is kinda out there though.  Great pictures in his slides too.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Hardest class I've ever taken. Tests are all free response and ask for incredible amounts of detail. Test averages were in the 50s consistently. Powerpoints do not have all of the information you need to know on them and he goes super fast in lectures. If I could do it again I would avoid him at all costs.

The Biotech FYS is not wonderful, but not horrible or difficult.  There's not much work, and you don't learn all that much.  Dr. Reed is a genuinely nice guy (he had the class over to his house for dinner!) but he's a botanist at heart (not the best as far as social skills go).  Material combines the biotech with the industry entrepreneurship.

As with all bio profs, he should not be teaching.  He belongs in a lab.  Very smart man, but not good at getting his point across.  He loves his projector & his tests are not representative of lecture.  You have to hope for a good TA that can teach u what u need to know.

The man is brilliant, in that 'i dont know how to talk to normal people' kind of way. moves fast, uses images to lecture by so you have to take notes fast on what he's saying. tests are rediculously hard and he likes it that way. averages on tests were in the 50's. Steve Rogers, who taught the first half was a lot better.

Teaches very fast but if you put the time in you can learn the material. This is a teach yourself course. Tests are NOTHING like what is taught. This class will put a major dent in your GPA. He will help in office hours but even with office hours and reading the book tests are EXTREMELY difficult. First test we had the whole class never finished!

Teaches fairly clearly, but tests are not at all representative of what he teaches. Final was almost exclusively over material covered very, very briefly or not at all. Hard to follow sometimes due to halting speech. Not recommended.

He is a very boring teacher and it was a horrible first year seminar. There is hardly any work but it is very boring. He also does not assign any grades, so you have no idea how you are doing in his class until the end.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Fantastic professor! Super knowledgeable on anything you ask, and if he doesn't know, he will do some research and answer your question the next lecture. Instead of a textbook he gives super specific weekly notes on topics he will cover. Always super available for questions and will make sure you understand everything. Definitely recommend!!

Excellent professor. He gives detailed lectures and does a great job of explaining material. The course is a lot of information, but he presents everything well. There is no textbook for this course, so you must go to lectures to learn. If you are at all interested in genetics, definitely take this course!

This class is very well taught and interesting. If you are at all interested in human genetics, I highly recommend this course. It's not super difficult, but you need to study and allocate some time to work on the problem sets. Dr. Sekelsky is really helpful. He posts lecture notes online that are really great to supplement your class notes.
Very intersting class and prof.   Very helpful and STRAIGHTFOWARD and funny. Great class
Engaging lecturer, very clear about what will and will not be on tests
Nice guy, actually tests on what he teaches
Interacts with the class well and always willing to go back and answer questions in the middle of the lecture.  Tests go along with the lectures.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Conlon is a decent professor, but it makes a lot more sense if you already know quite a bit about developmental biology. His lectures can definitely be confusing sometimes, but most of what you need to know is covered in class and not in the book. You should definitely study hard, but his tests really weren't too bad. Overall he's not that bad.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: It is true that his lectures are a little vague and he speaks really fast but there is a lot information that he has to cover in a small amount of time. He tries his best to be helpful and make the class interesting and overall is not a bad professor. The class is tough but the exams are not impossible and the curve is usually pretty good.

Umbanhowar's lectures are worthless. He stands up there and discusses vague examples and graphs, and doesn't have a clear point. It's better to just read the textbook to understand the material. The tests aren't too hard and are curved ALOT because everyone does poorly. I would stay away from him and his poor ecology teachings.
Absolutely terrible.  Lectures made 0 sense. The recitations are the only thing that  saved me from failing

Terrible.  Not even worth going to class.  I started reading the book before the class lectures and I started to think I could have taught the class better than he did.  He stutters a lot and spends the vast majority of the time talking about simple concepts and completely avoids the nitty-gritty details.  I also hated his voice.

Here's the deal: any class you take with this man will most likely end up in you getting a low grade UNLESS you have the initiative to read the book and study a LOT. The recitation section was helpful, but the professor himself is worthless. He jumps around in his lectures, he is hard to follow, and his exams are hard. Just saying' good luck.
Terrible professor, I could barely understand what he was saying because he mumbles and corrects himself so much. Regularly cancelled office hours and did not seem invested in teaching.
Avoid! He mumbles and has no clue what he is saying half the time. His drawing and diagrams are completely useless. You will be teaching yourself from the book if you want to even pass

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Burch definitely has positive and negative aspects. I enjoyed the class, and the outlines were helpful, but we never really finished them during class. Also there were optional book readings that I found to be completely unnecessary, and oftentimes what was said in the book was never actually tested on. Her office hours are very helpful!

Dr. Burch was just not very good, and she was boring for the most part. You have outlines to fill out, but she doesn't time her lectures very well and you don't have time to finish the outlines. But she still tests you on info from that outline that she didn't even cover. Nice lady but difficult exams and info not presented well
Doesn't finish the lectures or outlines and you are often left having to learn the material for a test without having gone over it in class.

Avoid taking her. Lectures are boring and monotonous. Power points aren't really organized. On her second test she asked loads of questions about the material she barely went over in class. Very bad when it comes to responding the emails. TAs do all the work. Recitations are a total waste of your life.
She sounded kind of out of breath a lot of the times, but she's really not bad.  Definitely a very smart woman and not bad at communicating the ideas she wants you to understand.

She gives you outlines before class so all you have to do is write down minimal notes in class.  The tests weren't really that hard and the material was actually pretty interesting.  The recitation is a little to much work though.

Reasonably good professor but boring and slow-moving at times. Gives relatively easy tests, but requires attendance and participation in recitation, unlike most Bio classes. She also requires a 4-page paper that's just a giant hassle.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Had Kieber for the 2nd half of BIO 202, and it was a rude awakening after Hogan. He was poorly organized and his slides were difficult to follow. He didn't explain concepts well at all, and sometimes concepts he said wouldn't be on the exam showed up anyways. Did not answer multiple emails. He doesn't seem interested in teaching. Avoid if possible!

Awesome prof! He goes really fast but is willing to slow down if you let him know. There's a lot of info we have to know for the exam, but the midterm wasn't tricky (haven't taken final yet). Only grades are midterm, a project, and a final. Even though he posts the power points on Sakai, you need to go to class in order to do well on the exam

lectures are rambling and pointless, you you'd better go for your poll everywhere grade, which I didn't sometimes and suffered. leaves you with substitutes randomly, who are actually better lecturers. The exams are traps to see if you are an expert in the confusing subject matter. He says it wont cover things we didn't cover, but it's a lie.

Dr. Kieber is the worst professor I have had at UNC. His lectures are boring, he rambles and is super unclear about the material, and he is kind of a smart ass in office hours. He constantly told us in class to not worry about the small details but still tested us on those details. Smart guy but he should stick to research. NOT a good teacher!

I love Kieber. He's very enthusiastic and he makes great lame jokes. His lectures are entertaining. Yeah, he goes fast, but if you take notes and put in some time outside of class you'll be okay. Definitely highly recommend him if you're interested in genetics. I hated Hogan's half (way boring) and loved his.

Dr. Kieber is really smart but you can tell he's a professor because he wants to do research not because he wants to teach. He's kind of awkward and goofy but overall a nice guy. He goes over material quickly so I suggest recording lectures. His tests are really straightforward but not the easiest. Overall not a bad choice for 202.

He's a good professor and an approachable guy.  Study the material from lecture hard and you'll do fine in the class.  Don't worry so much about the textbook; work practice problems from the recitation.

Kieber teaches the second half of Bio 202. He has a lot of energy, however because he must cover such a large amount of material, he is often times VERY unclear about what he's trying to say. Almost to the point of frustration. Be prepared to read the textbook or spend a long time teaching yourself the material. Overall a hard class in general.

first off, the class is curved. the averages for all the exams are generally in the low 60s. without a curve, statistically, the average grade is a D-. That being said its hard to dislike dr. kieber because hes so enthusiastic and is a nice guy overall, but he tries to cover far too much material to be testing on such small details.
YOU NEED TO ATTEND EVERY CLASS!!! otherwise ur gonna regret a lot afterwards b/c the exams are really detailed.personally, had hard time following his lecture. but, some ppl liked his style.

I thought Kieber would be straightfwd, b/c at first he made it clear what was expected.Nice guy, but his teaching style did not work for me.  His combined final with Hogan was VERY DETAILED and cummulative.  I thought for sure teh class would be curved, or the lowest test dropped, but niether happend, and your grade was just your grade.  GOOD LUCK!

HARD class!  I would just avoid it if you can.  I had to email him to ask questions a few times, and he never responded.  He seems like a nice intelligent guy and I'm sure he works for some people, but he moves through the material very quickly.
he's a great professor... you work, but end up KNOWING the material.  he'll also go out of his way to write you a letter of recommendation, if you ask.
HE TALKS>>>> AND TALKS>>>> AND TALKZZzzzzzzzzzz.... (=_=). Do the reading and HW, and don't forget to bring your pillow.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: This class is both extremely fascinating and challenging; I didn't know anything about computational genetics before, but I'm now interested in pursuing this important discipline of biology in the future. Dr. Vision uses a lot of interesting examples to explain complex (and potentially boring) topics. He is clear, fair, and obviously passionate.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Felt like his lectures were in another language. When no one in lecture is able to answer his questions, he doesn't go back over the material, just moves on. When a question is asked in lecture he is even able to explain his answer, just attributes the confusion to a poorly worded question instead.
His lectures are really informative and he is really helpful after class. The exams were tough but I felt prepared by listening to his lectures (the curve helped a lot).

Contrary to the other reviews, I thought Professor Willett clearly defined his expectations. The tests were similar to the practice tests, and his lectures, while a little boring, went into the same level of depth that he expected students to go into on the exam. I never went to office hours, but he seemed nice enough in class.

Dr. Willett seems kind, but he is not a crystal clear lecturer and his expectations are not clearly defined. However, his tests are not terrible. They closely resemble the practice tests he gives students beforehand. Lectures are mandatory for success. Textbook is used lightly, but if you truly want to do well, do all the assigned reading.

Avoid if possible. This guy is condescending and does not care about his students. He makes his tests harder than they need to be, and he focuses on details that are too specific for the amount of material covered. He's a researcher, not a teacher.

NO NO NO NO. His lectures are so boring and so disorganized.  He doesnt fill them in all the way so you have to go sit through his boring class to fill in the definitions and formulas he wants you to know for the test and then the notes are so disorganized you have to go back and reorder them just so you can re-teach yourself the material. AVOID.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Before I decided to take his class, I remember visiting this site. I remember many people saying that this was the professor that they had ever had, and now, I think the same thing. However, don't underestimate the work load. Anatomy in general is tough, but you are still expected to know just as much as any other course.

Great lecturer, who knows his stuff. If you're fascinated by the human body, this class will give you the satisfaction of deeply exploring its marvels. I must say that since 92% of your overall grade is test average, the pressure to perform is always there... which amounts to many hours of studying notes and textbook material.
Dr. Shemer is a genius and makes class really interesting. The tests are fair for what is covered in lecture, but sometimes the multiple choice is tricky

Great teacher! Shemer is very knowledgeable about biology and answers any questions you have really well or to the best of his ability. He assigns just the few pages of reading that you need and goes over topics in detail during class so everything that will be on the test will be explained in person. Take lots of notes during lecture.

Dr. Shemer is the best professor I've encountered in the biology department. His lectures are clear and well organized, he's interactive with the class, and takes questions often and seems to really care if we understand the material.  He gives a lot of practice for the tests and his review sessions are super helpful.

Shemer is one of the most intelligent lecturers I have ever had. He makes attending lecture interesting and worth my while. There is a TON of material, but that is with the nature of the class. He also only has two exams, and then the final, so there is more pressure on those two classes. You really cannot find a better professor for the material.

The class is hard, but very fair. Shemer is a great teacher and gives lots of resources for extra help. If you study the material along the way and don't wait until the weekend before the test, you'll be fine. Lab is worth a big part of your grade, so study hard for that too and you'll be fine

Great professor. Very funny, loves what he teaches, crystal clear. His exams are not bad, makes you think and apply your knowledge, if you study his notes and understand the material well, you'll be fine
Passionate, interesting, knowledgeable, and humorous.  His exam are fair but challenging.  I highly recommend him for A&P.
He is fabulous. hard and expects a lot from his students but truly one of the best at UNC. He is a must!

Shemer is passionate about what he teaches and truly tries to integrate the entire class in his lectures. But his tests are very unfair. I studied for weeks before and still did badly on them. He even said in class "I know that some of you are studying a lot and still doing bad. Don't be discouraged." Great, but my Gpa is messed up bc of this! :/

He is very funny and a nice guy! His lectures are interesting, but his tests are the hardest tests I have ever taken. I would put in over 20 hours studying and just do decent on the test. Also you HAVE to go to class. He tests you on stuff that he just says in class and is not in the book or on powerpoints.

Very difficult class, especially for someone who is not interested in science. However, I absolutely loved this class. I enjoyed going every day. His tests are very hard, but he's also clear on what to expect. Study hard and often, and enjoy his funny lectures!

Anatomy with Shemer was one of my favorite classes at UNC. It was entertaining, interesting, & funny & he was always available in office hours. Exams were challenging but it was clear what to expect; they were multiple choice, t/f, & fill-in-the-blank, requiring higher-level thinking. He scheduled exams so they wouldn?t conflict with lab exams.
An all around good fellow. He has high expectations not for the purpose of maintaining a curve, but because he is genuinely concerned if you do well.

He is INCREDIBLE!  He is so interested in the subject matter and he brings a lot of energy to the class, so lectures are a lot of fun.  He talks quickly, so I would recommend a recorder.  He also offers extra credit for a few people if they want to write a song about anatomy and perform it!  He is always willing to give additional explanations.

Prof. Shemer is one of the best professors I've ever had.  Although the course isn't easy due to the breath of material covered, Shemer is very clear in explaining what you need to know.  He's entertaining, keeps the class engaged and his powerpoints are very helpful.  Definitely recommend this class! (but must you must study regularly to do well).

This class is pretty hard but he is definitely a great teacher. He really cares that you learn the material. Just make sure you the information like the back of your hand. Would definitely suggest this class.

Awesome teacher! Difficult material, but what else would you expect with the human body. His speech is hard to understand at times but he does all he can to help you out. Overall this was one of my favorite classes at UNC.
Loved him!  No curve though.  Class is really fun, and he's hilarious.  Make sure you go to class and read.  This was my favorite class at Chapel Hill.
